Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The role of natural enemies and resource availability in biological invasions by plants
Award.AbstractNarration:
One likely reason that some of the plant species introduced by humans to new regions are able to spread and outcompete native plants is that the introduced plants are relatively free from natural enemies such as herbivores and pathogens. However, the benefits to an introduced species of release from enemies may depend on the levels of resources such as soil nutrients in the new habitat. In more fertile habitats, many plants grow more rapidly and lower their chemical or physical defenses against enemies. This should increase the advantage of the absence of enemies and thus the ability of introduced plants to outcompete native ones. This project will test this resource-enemy release hypothesis of biological invasion through a series of experiments in which 6 introduced species and 14 native species are grown at different levels of soil fertility and with and without protection from native insect herbivores and fungal pathogens.

Understanding the factors that allow some introduced species to become dominant in their new ranges is critical for natural resource management. Invasive species cause declines in biodiversity and cost the U.S. economy nearly $120 billion annually. Results from this project will help managers target control to the habitats and species most at risk. The project will also provide hands-on research experience in field and laboratory settings to several undergraduate students, and disseminate findings to high school biology classes and the local community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biological invasions—the establishment and spread of species outside their historical native ranges—has implications for basic ecology as well as conservation and human well-being. Invasions can also provide insights into natural processes that would be difficult or impossible to experimentally manipulate. Thus, identifying the mechanisms that promote invasions is crucial for both applied and basic ecology. However, species invasions are complex processes that depend on multiple factors, complicating management efforts.

While most major invasion hypotheses focus on a single causal mechanism (for example, nutrient availability, or traits of the invasive species), this research examined whether trade-offs between resource allocation to growth of new tissue and defense of tissue against disease and herbivory can explain why some non-native species become invasive in their new range and others do not. Upon introduction, many non-native species escape from their specialist natural enemies (herbivores and pathogens that attack one or a few closely related species). The degree to which escape from enemies benefits these exotic species may depend on the physiological traits of the individual. Plants experience a trade-off between rapid growth and defense against enemies (for example, with thorns or toxic compounds). Plants adapted to fertile soils tend to acquire nutrients quickly and typically allocate most of their resources (sugars, nutrients) to growth and reproduction rather than defense. Because the relative cost of defending rapidly growing tissue is greater than the cost of defending slow-growing tissue, these quick-growing individuals may be more susceptible to damage from enemies. These plants subsequently experience a great benefit from escaping their specialist enemies. Conversely, plants that occur in infertile soils typically allocate a large portion of their resources toward defending their tissue. These slow-growing, well-defended individuals may experience less damage from enemies (due to their large defense investment) and receive a much smaller benefit from enemy escape. Increased soil fertility typically increases allocation of a plant’s resources to growth and reproduction at the expense of defense investment. Thus, fertilization of the native community often increases their susceptibility to fungal diseases and insect herbivory. This may reduce the competitive ability of natives relative to non-natives experiencing enemy escape, particularly in fertile soil.  Ultimately, this leads to the general hypothesis that non-native plants will outperform native plants in fertile soil if the non-native plants have escaped from their herbivores and pathogens.

We tested this hypothesis in a field experiment in vegetation containing both native and non-native plant species. To determine whether enemies impacted native species more than non-native species, we excluded mammalian herbivores from plots with fences and excluded insect herbivores and fungal pathogens from plots by applying pesticides. If herbivores and pathogens have larger negative impacts on native species, excluding them should benefit native species relative to non-natives. Furthermore, if non-native species gain a greater benefit from enemy escape in fertile soils, then excluding enemies should benefit native species most in fertilized plots. Both fencing and pesticide application reduced the success of non-native species relative to native species, indicating that herbivores and pathogens had stronger negative impacts on native species. In support of our hypothesis, fencing reduced the success of non-native species most in fertilized plots.
